head.title: Lure the Best to a Life of Teaching

hedline.hl1: Lure the Best to a Life of Teaching

abstract.p: Katherine K Merseth letter on Harold O Levy's Sept 9 article deplores bureaucratic hurdles would-be teachers face in big-city school districts

block.p: Re ''Why the Best Don't Teach,'' by Harold O. Levy (Op-Ed, Sept. 9):
Re ''Why the Best Don't Teach,'' by Harold O. Levy (Op-Ed, Sept. 9):

Graduates of the Harvard Graduate School of Education Teacher Education Programs, including its Mid-Career Math and Science Program for career changers, are among the best and the brightest of all Harvard graduate students. Yet the maze of certification papers, bureaucratic hurdles and application procedures that these teachers must navigate in order to teach in big-city school districts makes landing a job at any point before the first few hours of school nearly impossible.

In Boston, more than 25 distinct steps and 9 different signatures are required from the point of application to final hire. It is no wonder that this disincentive, among others, gives us the teaching work force we have.
KATHERINE K. MERSETH Cambridge, Mass., Sept. 11, 2000
The writer is a lecturer on education at Harvard University.
